diplomacy_strings.string: The Fujiwara are honoured and pleased to accept this offer. May fortune favour our future dealings.
You are a blessing to your family, and to the Fujiwara. We accept whole-heartedly.
A marriage between your family and the Fujiwara brings many advantages. Let it be done.
We would have dealings with you, as your honesty and worth mirror that of the Fujiwara clan.
My heart is heavy, but the Fujiwara no longer see any profit in trading with you.
This is unfortunate. We Fujiwara could not accept such an offer.
While what you suggest has merits, we Fujiwara cannout accept it.
I must take my leave. Other family duties demand my attention if the interests of the Fujiwara are to be properly served.
Welcome! The Fujiwara pride themselves on remembering friends, and on honouring them.
It is good to see an honourable friend of the Fujiwara in these times! What shall we talk of?
The Fujiwara do not sell their children into bondage. You will have no hostage today.
Our Fujiwara ancestors would not sleep peacefully with your troops tramping across our hallowed lands.
You are mistaken. Fujiwara pride, and history, would never allow such a thing.
This is not the time to speak of peace. The sword of the Fujiwara has been drawn and it will not rest!
Good! The House of Minamoto welcomes open, honest war with you!
The Minamoto ancestors resent your soldiers disturbing their peace. Our lands are closed to you.
You would be wise to allow Minamoto armies to march across your lands.
No! Such scant fare would not sit well in Minamoto stomachs.
I will listen, but my Minamoto heart aches to see your blood spilled.
Minamoto flesh is not bought and sold in the market! There will be no hostage for you!
The Minamoto do not pimp their sons and daughters to the likes of you. There will be no marriage.
The House of Minamoto does not bow to anyone, except the Emperor!
Ha! You are a court fool to ask this! You will not have one rusty nail from Minamoto lands!
You will have nothing. We Minamoto do not pay for peace. Our swords guarantee our peace.
We Minamoto are not court lackeys! We cannot be bought like cheap dancing girls!
Minamoto gold will stay in Minamoto strongrooms. We do not meekly hand it to robbers.
Thank you, but no: we do not want your whelp cluttering up a Minamoto palace.
Be silent now. You have babbled your nonsense into Minamoto ears until we are weary. We are done.
There is much to celebrate here. The Taira always appreciate honest dealings!
Our discussions are complete, and most satisfactory. And now, court business requires my attention…
We Taira welcome your decision, and the wisdom that lies behind your choice.
The House of Taira has better things to occupy its attention than you. Our talks are done.
A marriage can bring only honour to both our families. The House of Taira welcomes you.
I see. The House of Taira truly hopes that you will not live to regret this decision.
Be wise: accept the truth. You need a powerful protector, and the Lord of the Taira is that man. Be his vassal.
A regular contribution to the treasury of the House of Taira would show that intelligence is not lacking in your family.
This offer is a bad joke! Do you think the Taira have are weak scribes to be so insulted?
Surely your enemies would quake to know you are an ally of the Taira. Accept our formal friendship and all will be well.
We offer you marriage, a union with the House of Taira: such an elevation should not be lightly refused.
The wise courtier knows that a gift can often smooth the way between friends. Please, accept this measure of Taira esteem.
There are matters of state that need attention. What inconvenience do you bring to the House of Taira?
An alliance may seem worthy to you, but the House of Taira sees little profit in such an arrangement.
This marriage honours you and strengthens the Chosokabe!
Honest, open war is better than mealy-mouthed peace. We will erect a monument to you, afterwards.
The Chosokabe no longer need your trade goods. Our arrangement is ended.
I see little point in talking further. Your ways are too subtle for me to comprehend their meaning.
Perhaps it is time to talk of peace. There is honour in peace made with strength.
You can surely see that trade brings both profit and friendship.
We offer the hand of a Chosokabe in marriage. What more could anyone want for his family?
Welcome! And what would you ask of the Chosokabe?
We do not give up our children to men such as you! The Chosokabe still believe in honour!
So, you think the Chosokabe so stupid that they will agree to any theft, no matter how prettily phrased?
We are not stupid. Why have peace when you still have breath to ask for it?
We will not be ruled by other men. Chosokabe honour has meaning, or it is nothing.
No, we are not so simple as to want peace just yet.
Your gold could not buy a Chosokabe nail paring, let alone our good opinion.

You gain much from our bloodline! Fortunately, the Date clan is also stronger as a result of this marriage.
An end to fighting does not diminish us, or you. It shows prudence and honour.
Never! Date lands are not your drill grounds!
We are our own masters! Do not be foolish and confuse negotiating with weakness.
Not one single coin will leave the Date treasury. Continue, and much blood will flow!
There can be no peace. We are fighters, not old women!
No. There are no members of the Date clan who would be suitable for such an honour.
We cannot allow that. Our warriors would, rightly, not suffer such shame in silence.
We are warriors. The Date do not bow to any unworthy men.
Ha! So you would rob us and call it diplomacy?
No. You still live.
A well-intentioned offer, but such a marriage is not possible for we Date.
Date honour is not bought with a handful of coins.
We welcome war. Our warriors yearn for it, as you will shortly discover.
Very well, let it be war. My profound condolences to your widows-to-be.
Let us build from strong foundations, and thrive together.
Our lands have been unquiet with your troops in them. We cannot allow this to continue.
Let us put matters on a firm footing: provide us with a hostage, as guarantee of your good behaviour.
It is time to end the fighting, before both our houses lie entirely ruined.
We will not give even one of our people into your tender care. You must think us foolish indeed!
No Hojo marriage bed will ever be soiled by one of your whelps!
Never! Hojo lands and honour are not yours to trample as you see fit!
We do not need your money. Our lands are quite wealthy enough without taking payments from peasants.
We may be known as builders, but we are not tradesmen to be bought in this fashion!
We cannot do such a thing. The very stones of our land would cry out against it.
Such an alliance would be built without foundations. It would collapse in the merest breeze.
No. Gifts honour the giver, but not in this case.
The Hojo have nevered feared war. They will not start now.
I would as soon drive a tanto into your heart, but this agreement must be accepted.
The Hattori understand such things. The matter will be arranged.
So be it! Now you will learn to fear the shadows!
There is much to be said for turning aside the resentment of others with golden blossoms.
Ah! If only good manners allowed me to carve this rejection into your skull!
We Hattori are not fools. This will be remembered.
Even now the clouds gather around the mountain tops, and sensible men go home.
What do you want? Speak, if you value your tongue!
Why have you come? Why should the Hattori listen to your words?
No Hattori could be persuaded to bed one of your creatures!
Hattori lands are not some pleasure garden for you to wander in as you see fit!
We do not give others gold, only steel. And in darkness.
To what end would the Hattori want you as allies? Target practice, perhaps?
When next you wake, if you wake, you will regret the decision to fight us, the Hattori!
A proposal as straight and true as an arrow's shaft! We accept. May good fortune favour us all.
We accept, even though you are lower than a snake's belly.
May this marriage further strengthen the bond between us.
War it is, then! You will be cast into the mud and trampled under our feet!
Your armies must never enter our lands again. They offend the people, the spirits and the heavens!
Like all nobles, you have talked and said nothing. This is ended.
Speak carefully, for you walk along the edge of a volcano!
Our people are not traded like cattle! There will be no hostage!
Marriage? To one of yours? Oh, no, no, no.
A rotten fish still stinks, even when dressed in the finest silk. Why would we want to be your slaves?
We will never be your slaves and servants. Find others to bow to you.
No. Our children are precious.
Peace? It is peace you want? We do not see the need for your peace!
War it is, then. Now you will feel the people's righteous fury!
A proposal as straight and true as an arrow's shaft! The Emperor will accept.
Your words are entirely sensible. I gladly accept on the Emperor's behalf.
The Imperial Court will accept these terms, even though you are lower than a snake's belly. I will bear the dishonour.
I will carry the shame of our acceptance. The Emperor's reputation will remain intact.
I am sure court will be angered, but we must agree with your proposal. For now.
Your proposal is, at best, disrespectful to His Majesty, but I will accept it. Abide your given word!
I accept on behalf of the Imperial Court. There: it is done.
I do not care for you or yours, but I will persuade the court to agree. That must be enough.
I still have reservations, but I will tell His Majesty that we have reached agreement here today.
Ah! Men like you should be serving His Majesty! We have an agreement, and honest friendship!
A most satisfactory end to our discussions. I express His Majesty's thanks for him.
Our alliance is ended. The next time we meet may be with guns and swords rather than tea cups.
Very well. Trade is beneath Imperial dignity anyway. It is over.
This is unfortunate. And I have know ladies discussing kimonos act with more decisiveness.
So we are done, then. So much for talking. I expressed concerns to His Majesty about just this outcome…
May this marriage further strengthen the bonds of loyalty to the Emperor.
Marriage should be a time of happiness. Let this one increase the happiness and trust in all our hearts.
A marriage is a sign of the sincerity in all our hearts. We agree.
This marriage should do much to ease any difficulties between you and the Imperial Court.
A marriage is a welcome sign of better times to come. I wish the couple much joy.
Politics and the marriage bed: they are a start towards better things, I trust.
Your decision is a courageous one, but I will carry word back to the Imperial Court.
Greetings, noble friend. I have come with a proposal from His Majesty that should also meet with your approval.
His Majesty commands me speak, and I obey, although I would sooner treat with ice-hearted demons.
The Emperor would know your mind on some trifling matters.
My words today carry the weight of Imperial authority. Listen with care.
My words are an offer from His Majesty's generous heart. Listen, and consider it with care.
His Majesty sends greetings. He also sends a noble proposal. You should listen.
I have come in search of wisdom in response to His Majesty's proposal. I hope this is not a vain exercise.
I speak at the court's behest. Its honour is indeed great, to send a proposal to such as you.
Recognising your worth, the Emperor sends gracious felicitations, and instructs me to make you an offer.
I bear greetings, and His Majesty's offer. Perhaps you will listen with wisdom and proper respect.
His Majesty sends his best wishes, and hopes that we may reach further harmony.
The spirits of Japan are unquiet. We can no longer allow your armies to disturb our tranquility.
Regretfully, Imperial edicts now forbid your merchants from further trade.
Your words have merit, as His Majesty will surely see. I accept your counter-proposal.
Your words lack substance, and I will risk Imperial displeasure by rejecting them immediately.
I will be plain: your future is bleak without a protector. Become an Imperial vassal, and secure your future.
I will not trouble the Emperor with the decision to reject this offer.
Your offer does little for the dignity of the Chrysanthemum Throne. Harmony would be lessened by our agreement.
Such an offer would not be acceptable within Imperial circles. I will not raise the matter with the Court.
This proposal is quite interesting, but completely out of the question as far as His Majesty is concerned.
All your words are a disguised insult to the Chrysanthemum Throne, not a sincere offer.
You must think His Majesty's servants are simple. I will only reply: "no".
Trade is beneath Imperial dignity, but allowing our merchants to work would be sensible.
A marriage into the Imperial family would benefit all, for it would be a sign of trust between us.
Perhaps you would consider a marriage into the Imperial family. Such a thing would do much to foster good relations.
I have other court duties, you know. Speak quickly, so that I may be about something useful today.
Speak, then, and do so with despatch. I have other pressing business with court officials.
Imperial flesh and blood are not traded like cattle! There will be no hostage!
I cannot think of any rational reason why one of your family should be allowed to marry so far above their station.
Why on earth would we link the Imperial family to anyone so far beneath them in blood and honour?
Ha! Never. The Imperial children will marry dung collectors before we consider any of your whelps!
Ah! You are a clan of merchants then! Well, the Emperor does not deal with merchants, ever!
Sadly, I do not think the Emperor would want his peace disturbed by the marching of your men.
An arranged marriage. I do not think this would work. The Emperor must maintain Imperial dignity.
No. I do not think the Emperor would sell his dignity, like some tradesman.
A proposal as straight and true as an arrow's shaft! The Shogunate accepts your offer.
Your words are entirely sensible. I gladly accept on the Shogunate's behalf.
Even though you are lower than a snake's belly we accept this offer. The dishonour is mine alone.
I will carry the shame of our acceptance. The Shogun's reputation will remain intact.
The Shogunate must agree with your proposal. For now.
I accept on behalf of my Shogun. There: it is done.
I do not care for you or yours, but I will persuade the Shogun to agree. That must be enough.
I still have reservations, but I will tell the Shogun that we have an agreement.
Your people are blessed to be served by you. We have an agreement, and honest friendship!
Our alliance is ended. The next time we meet may be with guns and swords rather than tea cups.
May this marriage further strengthen the bond between us.
Marriage should be a time of happiness. Let this one increase the happiness and trust between us.
A marriage is a sign of the sincerity in all our hearts. We agree.
This marriage should do much to ease any difficulties between us.
Your decision is a courageous one, but I will carry word of it to the Shogun.
Greetings, noble friend. I have come with a proposal from the Shogun that should also meet with your approval.
The Shogun commands me speak, and I obey, although I would sooner speak with barbarous foreigners.
The Shogun sends me to deal with you on some trifling matters.
My words today carry the weight of the Shogunate's authority. Listen with care.
My words are an offer from the Shogun's noble heart. Listen, and consider it with care.
The Shogun sends greetings. In this he is too generous. He also sends a proposal. You should listen.
I have come in search of wisdom in response to this proposal. I hope this is not a vain exercise.
I speak on the Shogunate's behalf, an honour indeed. So perhaps you should listen.
Recognising your worth, the Shogun sends greetings, and instructs me to make you an offer.
I bear greetings, and the Shogun's offer. Perhaps you will listen with wisdom and friendship.
The Shogun sends his best wishes, and hopes that we may reach further agreement.
Your troops disturb the dignity of the Shogunate. It is time for them to leave our lands.
Regretfully, the Shogun now forbids his merchants from trading with your merchants.
Your words have merit, and I am sure the Shogun will approve. I accept your counter-proposal.
I will be plain: your future is bleak without a protector. Become a vassal of the Shogunate, and secure your well-being.
On the Shogun's behalf, I will decline this offer. I will not trouble him with the decision.
Your offer does little for the Shogunate. Our harmony would be lessened by accepting.
Such an offer would not be acceptable to the Shogun. I will not bring the matter to his attention.
All your words disguised only an insult to the Shogunate, not a sincere offer. And insulted, we refuse you anything.
Perhaps you would consider a marriage. Such a thing would do much to foster good relations.
I must tell you that the Shogun would sooner see a leatherworker wed to one of his own.
Ha! Never. The Shogun's children will marry dung collectors before they consider any of your whelps!
Ah! You are a clan of merchants then! Well, the Shogunate does not deal with merchants, or pay them without reason!
Sadly, I do not think the Shogun would want his peace disturbed by the marching of your men.
An arranged marriage. I do not think this would work. The Shogun is quite particular about his relatives.
No. I do not think the Shogun would accept payment, like some tradesman.
We do not care to be thought of as cheap foreigners, to be bought off for a handful of coins.
A proposal as straight and true as an arrow's shaft! My lord will accept. May good fortune favour us all.
Your words are entirely sensible. I gladly accept on my lord's behalf.
We can agree to such a sensible and correct proposal. Our thanks for your wisdom.
A wise proposal, and one that favours us all. We accept!
The good sense of your words cannot be denied. We accept, my friend.
Ah! This is a good end to our negotiations. We are in friendly agreement and all is well.
So we have agreement then! It is good when friends treat each other with respect!
An excellent suggestion. I agree. Wisdom and respect have prevailed.
So we are done, and we have a most acceptable agreement - and all in the spirit of friendship!
You have shown friendship and respect here today. How can I do less? I agree.
My lord will accept, even though you are lower than a snake's belly. I will carry the dishonour of this decision for him.
I will carry the shame of our acceptance. My lord's reputation will remain intact.
I am sure my lord will be angry, but we must agree with your proposal. For now.
My stomach troubles me. I… I… I agree. See that you keep your word!
I can see vile treachery in your heart even as I say this: we agree. Bah!
I see that we have no choice but to accept, though it makes my heart ache to do it.
We have reached agreement. Let us speak no more. I would bathe and get your stink off my flesh.
Your proposal is, at best, disrespectful, but I will accept it. See that you abide by what you have said!
Any shame for accepting this agreement will be on my head. Any shame for breaking it, on yours!
I would sooner take the word of a fox, but I must agree.
We have reached agreement, then, although the sake has unfortunately run out and we cannot celebrate.
So, we are in agreement then. Honesty and respect have informed our dealings.
This is acceptable. When honest men deal honestly with each other, we can reach agreement.
An acceptable offer. It is good to speak plainly, is it not?
Your words are acceptable, and we are in agreement. There is no more.
No more talk! The deal is done. Let us leave matters here, and go our separate ways.
I accept on behalf of my clan. There: it is done.
Your terms are acceptable. Let us see what the future brings.
Talk no more. Your offer will be accepted. Be glad of what you have achieved today.
No more. No more. There is nothing more to say. We accept.
Against all reason, we agree. We are not friends, but we are not enemies. That will have to suffice.
I do not care for you or yours, but I will persuade my lord to agree. That must be enough.
I still have reservations, but I will tell my lord that we have reached agreement here today.
My heart is full of foreboding that this will be an evil thing, but I accept.
I accept your terms, although it is an ill-done act. I hope no further ill comes of it.
An end to this tittle-tattle! The deal is done. Do not look for anything more.
Enough! Your words are wearisome, but I accept your proposal.
I would prefer the word of a gentleman, but I must take yours. I will agree to your terms.
I will accept your terms. My heart tells me that you are false, but we shall see.
I accept your offer. See to it that you honour your side of the bargain!
It is heartening to see honour still exists in these treacherous times: you are a blessing to your clan.
Your lord is blessed to be served by men like you. We have an agreement, and honest friendship!
And so we have an agreement! When friendship and statecraft meet, how could it be otherwise?
Let me be the first to express agreement with what is proposed. This is an auspicious day!
I accept! Your terms are even-handed and fair, your words respectful and becoming to your honour.
So, the deal is done. Excellent! We march on in friendship, to the consternation of our rivals!
Our rivals will tremble when they hear of this agreement, my friend! Excellent!
How could I refuse such an offer from a friend such as you? I cannot!
Ah, your diplomatic skills match your worth in friendship! We gladly accept.
Truly, my friend, your arguments have won the day! I accept your offer.
A most satisfactory end to our discussions. Our thanks.
This is a good end to an honourable meeting of warriors. My thanks for your sincerity.
A good ending for our talk, then. Diplomacy can, and has, achieved much!
We have an agreement then. Honourable men can always find a way.
Good. We are in agreement. Such is the way of the world when honest men speak.
Excellent. Your good sense does your clan credit.
Your skills as a diplomat do your clan much credit.
It is good to talk to a respectful and respected man, and to reach agreement in that fashion.
My thanks for your words, and for your agreement.
My thanks for your wisdom, and for this agreement.
Our alliance is ended. The next time we meet may be with swords rather than tea cups.
So our alliance is over. We are not enemies, perhaps, but we are no longer friends.
Our alliance has served its purpose, and now we are done. There is little more to say.
Sometimes the blossom falls on a still lake, and sometimes on a grave.
All things have a season, and winter has come to our alliance. It is ended as you say.
It will be as you say. Our alliance will no longer cause fear in our rivals.
Very well, we will no longer march across your lands. We hope your safety will not suffer.
Very well. Our troops will have to march further. They will be toughened by the experience.
I am sure you have your reasons for this refusal. I hope they are worth our inconvenience.
This is an unfortunate day. Our troops much enjoyed the beauty of your lands. They will be saddened.
I appreciate candour. It is honest to say that you no longer wish friends to visit.
We will respect your decision. Our soldiers will be sad. They enjoyed many pleasures in your lands.
Very well, you trade goods were not what our people wanted anyway. I am sure your cheap geegaws will sell elsewhere.
The trade was welcomed by our people, but so be it. Your merchants were largely unwashed and will not be missed.
Very well. Trade is not a fit subject for warriors to discuss anyway. It is over.
There is much wisdom in your decision, and in your long deliberations.
Careful deliberation has brought welcome agreement after all.
It is good to reach an accord. Let us hope it does not melt away like winter's snows.
We have talked long, and discussed many things. In the end, wisdom has prevailed, as it should.
So we are agreed, then. Your final offer has brought us to a good conclusion.
We accept. Your offer is not what we looked for, but it is an acceptable arrangement.
It seems little is pleasing to you, then. Our talks must now conclude.
This is unfortunate. And I have known fish-wives make up their minds with more despatch!
So we have failed to reach accord. This is honest, at least.
We have talked, and know each others' hearts better. For now then, we go our separate ways.
So we have failed. Much talking has done little, save allow the tea to grow cold.
So we are done, then. So much for talking. I warned my lord that this might be the outcome…
A hostage. Yes. We will agree to such an arrangement.
Very well, we will give a home to one of your family. As long as treaties are honoured, of course…
Your offer of a hostage shows a realistic grasp of ideas. This will do much to avoid unpleasantness.
To give up one of your own shows much sincerity. It is a good thing.
You recognise the reality of your position. Good. The hostage will be treated with respect.
Very well. We will take a hostage, and you will remember that their life is in your hands.
May this marriage further strengthen the bond between the clans.
Marriage should be a time of happiness. Let this one increase the happiness and trust in both our lands.
A marriage is a sign of the sincerity in all our hearts. We agree.
This marriage should do much to ease any difficulties between our clans.
A marriage is a welcome sign of better times to come. I wish the couple much joy.
Politics and the marriage bed: they are a start towards better things, I trust.
This is most unfortunate. I hope that you will have no cause to regret this decision.
Very well. I shall report your rejection. You are honest in your decision, and we respect that.
Your decision is a courageous one, but I will carry word of it to my clan.
Long have we talked, and with honesty. Your decision demonstrates sincerity.
So we cannot reach agreement. At least you have spoken with commendable honesty.
Very well. We finish on a note of disagreement. Sometimes such things are meant to be.
A proposal as straight and true as an arrow's shaft! My lord will accept. May good fortune favour us all.
Ah! It is good to have open disagreement! We will put words aside: war it is!
Good! I had grown weary of talking when there is work for proper men. I look forward to taking your life!
War it is then. Many men will die because of the words spoken here.
I hope you live long enough to recognise your foolishness, but not long after that.
Your widows and orphans will soon be weeping at your foolishness today.
So, you have decided to die in battle. We shall do our very best to give you an honourable death.
Wives and children will curse your name for what you have decided to do today.
War, then, is your decision. I trust you will be among the first to die!
If we are to have war, then so be it. I look forward to saying prayers for your soul.
So war has come. It is better this way. Japan will be better when you are safely dead.
Please consider this offer carefully, so we may prosper together in friendship.
Greetings, noble friend. I have come with a proposal from my lord that should also meet with your approval.
My honoured friend, I bring a proposal that should meet with your approval.
It is always an honour to speak with you, and I anticipate your wise agreement today.
I have come with a proposal and, sure of your reasonable response, wish to put it to you.
Our greetings to you. In a spirit of friendship, we are keen to know your mind concerning this proposal.
I come bearing friendly greetings, and a friendly proposal. Will you listen to my words?
My duty here is born of friendship, my words of the perilous times we live in.
I offer only further friendship, made plain in the words that I speak here today.
It is good to speak with you, my friend. I have a proposal that may profit us both greatly!
You would be wise to consider this offer, as the world is a hostile place to those without friends.
A wise man would listen to my words. Of course, wisdom may be in short supply among your kind.
My lord commands me to speak, and I obey, although I would sooner treat with ice-hearted demons.
I speak to you today with reluctance. Try to listen carefully, and I will try to forget who you are.
I am here to put a proposal to you, rather than take your head. Would that it were the latter…
Do you notice a peculiar smell? No? Ah… I am here to put a proposal to you.
I would normally be happier treating with a leper, but I am ordered to put a proposal to you…
Is this the best you can do for an envoy? Pah! Very well, listen to my words, and think before you reply!
I did not come here to bandy pleasantries. I came, as ordered, to make you an offer.
You are known to be without honour, but these times make for strange meetings. Listen, then.
Perhaps you could consider this offer: agreement between us could prove fruitful.
I have come to make an open and honest offer. You will either accept it or not. What say you?
I have a proposal. If you listen, you may profit. If you do not, well, we will not suffer.
I bear greetings, and a proposal. A wise man might listen to both.
I come with greetings, and would know your mind on a matter of some importance.
Greetings. I am sent today to carry a proposal to you and to carry away your hopefully wise response.
My lord sends me to know your mind on some trifling matters.
I am sent so that we may avoid unfortunate misunderstandings.
My words today carry the weight of my lord's honour. Listen with care.
My words are an offer from my lord's generous heart. Listen, and consider it with care.
Let us speak together. We will pretend that you are honest men, and deal with you as such.
Let us speak briefly, so that I may be gone. There is a peculiar smell around here…
I will start with honesty: I would not choose to be here. But here I am, and I will speak.
My lord sends greetings. In this he is too generous. He also sends a proposal. You should listen.
I have come in search of wisdom in response to my lord's proposal. I hope this is not a vain exercise.
I doubt that we can reach agreement with such as you, but I must try. Listen carefully.
I will say what I must, and then listen to your reply. But no more than that.
I speak on my lord's part. His honour is indeed deep, to send a proposal to such as you.
Despite your reputation, I have come with an offer. Listen, then, and consider.
We have heard that you have-- native cunning. Perhaps this will serve in place of wisdom as you listen to my words.
Let us speak together in honour and friendship, as honest men do.
Recognising your worth, my lord sends greetings, and instructs me to make you an offer.
It is always good to speak with friends, and for friends to do well by each other.
When honest men speak together in open friendship, let their unworthy rivals cringe in fear!
I bear greetings to you, noble friend. I am sent with a proposal I am sure will meet with your approval!
I am sent with a proposal that I think will be most pleasing to you, my friend. Listen, and decide for yourself…
